title: PhD candidate: Quantum transport modeling of heat in nanostructures
location: Jardin du Pharo 58, bd Charles Livon Marseille, France
field: Electrical Engineering, Fluid Dynamics, Materials Physics, Nanotechnology, Quantum Physics, and 1 moreThermodynamics
job_description: Context and subject:Electronic device downscaling led to very detrimental self-heating effect due to the thermalization of hot carriers generated by high electric fields. However, despite its importance, the problem of heat flow at the nanoscale is still much less understood than the one of electronic transport, and research work must be urgently carried out to solve this issue. We have recently developed an âin-houseâ quantum transport code of phonons based on the Non-Equilibrium Green's Function (NEGF) formalism [see Ref. 1-3 for more details]. The NEGF approach has been recognized since several years as one of the best-suited methods to realistically describe quantum transport in nano-devices. Based on this code, the PhD candidate will theoretically investigate the heat transport in various technologically relevant systems, like Si/Ge interfaces, semiconductor heterostructures and 2D materials architectures. He/she will have to answer open questions about the transport mechanisms of phonons in those systems and to propose original thermal management solutions.Eligibility criteria of the applicants:Applicants must hold a master degree in physics, material science or electrical engineering.
